content: How can I help you today?

I've been struggling a lot lately. My son has been acting out, and my wife and I just can't seem to figure out how to help him. It's putting so much strain on our marriage, and I feel like everything is falling apart. I don’t even know if therapy is going to help, but my wife insisted I try.

Thank you for sharing what's been going on—it sounds like you're juggling a lot between your concerns for your son and the strain it’s putting on your relationship. It must feel overwhelming. What would you like to focus on as we talk today?

I guess I just really need help figuring out where to even start. Should I focus on helping my son first or trying to fix things with my wife? It all feels so tangled together, I don’t know what to do.

It's understandable to feel stuck when everything feels interconnected like this. Deciding where to start can be tough. Both your concerns—helping your son and strengthening your relationship—sound deeply important to you. What matters most to you right now, or feels like it might make the biggest difference overall?

I think what matters most is helping my son. If we can figure out what’s going on with him and help him, maybe it will take some pressure off my wife and me. But at the same time, I feel like my wife and I aren’t on the same page, and I don’t know if we can handle this together.

It sounds like your priority is supporting your son, but you're also aware that feeling disconnected with your wife might make it hard to navigate this together. You're carrying a lot, wanting to make changes for your son while also considering the health of your marriage. What do you think might help you and your wife work together more effectively to support him?

I’m honestly not sure—I feel like we’ve been trying everything, and all it does is lead to more arguments. We’re both so frustrated, and sometimes it feels like we’re blaming each other instead of working as a team. I don’t even know how to start fixing that.

It sounds like the cycle of frustration and blame has made things feel even harder for both of you, especially when you're trying to do your best for your son. It shows how much you care that you're reflecting on this right now. What do you think might need to happen for those conversations with your wife to start feeling less tense or more supportive?

It’s hard to say. I think we both need to feel heard, but we’re so stressed that it feels like we’re just talking past each other. Maybe if we could just figure out a way to communicate better without it turning into a fight, things might improve.

Wanting mutual understanding and a calmer way to communicate without conflict sounds like a meaningful first step. It speaks to how much you want to work together and strengthen what you have. What do you think you and your wife could try to create that space—where both of you feel heard and supported?

Maybe having some set times to talk when we’re both calm and away from the chaos at home would help. It’s hard because we’re both so tired and stressed, but I guess we need to make it a priority and try to listen to each other better. I just don’t know how to start that kind of conversation without it blowing up.

Choosing calmer moments and setting aside time to talk sounds like a thoughtful idea—it shows you’re looking for a way to rebuild understanding. Starting that conversation may feel tricky, especially with the stress you're both under. How might you approach sharing your idea in a way that feels safe and constructive for both of you?

I think I just need to tell her how much I care about fixing things and that I want us to really work together for the sake of our family. Maybe if I approach it calmly and focus on how much I value her, she’ll be more open to working on it with me. It’s just hard when emotions get so high.

Expressing how much you care and value her while focusing on your shared goals for your family sounds like a thoughtful way to approach the conversation. It shows your desire to build connection and teamwork through calm communication. When emotions run high, is there anything you’ve found helps you or her to pause and refocus during the tougher moments?

I guess just stepping away for a little bit helps sometimes. Giving ourselves a moment to calm down instead of pushing through when we're both upset might make it easier to actually hear each other. But in the heat of the moment, it's so hard to step back.

Taking a moment to step back and calm down sounds like a helpful strategy—giving you both the space to approach things with a clearer perspective. It’s understandable that it feels difficult in the moment, especially when emotions are running high. What might make it easier for either of you to recognize when it’s time to pause and step away?

Maybe if we had a plan in place, like agreeing on a code word or something that signals we need a break, it could help. I think it would remind us we’re trying to work together instead of fighting. But I’m not sure if she’ll be on board with that.

Having a plan, like a code word, sounds like a great way to foster teamwork and create a moment to pause when things feel heated. It shows your effort to approach these situations proactively. Sharing why this idea matters to you could help her see the intention behind it. Would you feel comfortable talking to her about this and how it could help you both move forward together?

It can be tough bringing ideas like this up, especially with everything you've been going through. But explaining it as a way to make things easier for both of you, rather than placing blame, might help. Taking it one step at a time and being open about how much you want to work together could make a big difference. How do you feel about starting that conversation?

I think I can try. It’s daunting, but if I focus on explaining how much I care about her and our family rather than the stress we’re under, maybe she’ll be more receptive. I don’t want things to keep feeling stuck, so I guess I have to start somewhere.
